status_message_cleaned: What’s the difference between apple cider and apple juice? Preservability, for one. Apple cider is raw apple juice that hasn’t been filtered to remove pulp and sediment. It starts to ferment in about a week, so it’s mostly a seasonal beverage. Pasteurization can extend its shelf-life but can also make it taste bitter. Apple juice starts out as apple cider and is then filtered to remove pulp and sediment. It can take up to hours to filter really clear apple juice! But not anymore. Click to read how electroflotation makes clear and stable apple juice.

We’re hosting a tweet chat with the curators of the Canadian National Collection of Insects, Arachnids and Nematodes (CNC), one of the largest collections of its kind in the world. The CNC serves Canadian scientists who investigate problems in the fields of agriculture, biodiversity, genetics, biological control and other various forms of integrated pest management, and is part of an international network for other researchers, educators and policy-makers. link_name: Soil Fingerprinting: New Tool for Soil Analysis
status_message_cleaned: Today is Earth Day! Did you know that soil has a fingerprint and it's as unique as yours! It's based on a soil's chemical, physical, and biological properties. This innovation was developed by our research teams in Ontario and BC, collaborating with others in Germany. Unlike your fingerprint, a soil's fingerprint can change as its properties change. Comparing fingerprints from the same plot over time can help determine the health of soil and help soil conservation efforts. The soil fingerprinting framework tool is available in Ontario and will be available around the world in spring .
